Comment:
Hi everyone!

So, you have all enjoyed my near-miss victory against Pitroque (Charles)!  So, by the grace of God I kept my Class A rating.  Happily and slightly more convincingly, I found myself taking another two steps on the Yellow Brick Road towards the Kingdom of Expertdom.  We ended up in the endgame mentioned above where I had the pieces and Andy had the rook.  So, how did this all happen?  Well, read on .......

2. e3      - I usually open with e4 so this is a thematic mini-tournament based on the Stonewall System.  This MT arose from two unrated games between Brigadecommander (Janet) and Stalhandske (Torsten).  Well, here is the start of the stonewalling.

2. e3      - I usually open with e4 so this is a thematic mini-tournament based on the Stonewall System.  This MT arose from two unrated games between Brigadecommander (Janet) and Stalhandske (Torsten).  Well, here is the start of the stonewalling.
6. f4 - after some rapid piece development on both sides, this move sets up the Stonewall.  It is very hard for either side to get a result, but sometimes these breakthroughs do happen!

14. 0-0 - now is the time to tuck Henry away.  I know the Witch is there to greet him, but it will be a while before she can be joined by her colleagues.  In the meantime, consolidation is the key here!

14. ...... Ba6 - threatening a discovered attack on my rook.  I spoil the show by advancing my b pawn to its fourth rank.

25. ..... gxf6 - after this plethora of exchanges, black's kingside pawns have been separated.  But where do I go from here?  A further bit of consolidation to my  queenside pawns is needed - i.e. I need to get my a pawn away from Andy's lsb before I can get my rook into play.

28. Re2  - not g3?? as this allows Nf3+.

30. Bg3 - Fou Lenoir defends my g2 pawn by blocking that rook's line.  My rook now gets traded in for Andy's two pieces and the g2 pawn.  This will result in me having two pieces and a pawn against a rook.  Although it depends on the position and Coach Ion managed a victory with the rook, more times than not the two pieces are better.
